ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Chinese language and culture

This course is designed for students who want to continue learning advanced chinese in advanced topics, such as the history, culture, and politics of China. The most recent topic was the China-Taiwan tension. Another memorable topic was the difference between the east and west's architecture.
I improved my speaking and listening abilities in Chinese.
Improved Chinese on a variety of topics.
Increased comfort with Chinese, learned more vocabulary.
I made significant leaps in my Chinese fluency and additionally was able to really get more familiar with Chinese history and culture.
Loved this class and it really helped me improve my Chinese skills.
I learned many new words and improved my fluency and tones.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Wonderful instructor, very relevant content. To improve, perhaps give the students some choice in what they learn? My classmates mentioned that they didn't enjoy the textbook content and that made it a lot less fun

strengths: it is clear what we need to know and study because the quizzes, classroom lectures, and exam study guides will really drill it in through repetition.
weakness: there is a lot of work some times
I think there could be a bigger emphasis on writing abilities.
Liang Laoshi is amazing - one of the nicest professors I've had! I also really enjoyed the content covered. Sometimes the homework can feel a bit tedious but overall not difficult.
Constantly doing something for the class, keeps you on your toes.

I don't really like the method of the A cutoff to be at 96, because I think if there were no curve and the tests were just made harder, there would still be a good grade distribution.

However, I really enjoy the variety of projects and assignments the course had. I thought the textbook was great and classes were very engaging. I never was bored.

Strength - great way to get regular exposure to Chinese listen, reading, and writing. Not too challenging so good for intermediate level students.
Weakness - the 'talk to other students' exercises were not too helpful, should probably be reduced.
The course is well organized and goes through lots of material. There was a lot of busy-work for homework, though.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Highly! You learn a lot of applicable content.
yes absolutely! your chinese will improve
Yes, if you want to maintain your level of Chinese it's a good course to take.
Yes! For sure! The class is whatever you put in. If you put in effort your Chinese will improve or if you just trying to stay in practice you can do well without drowning in work.
Yes if you are serious about chinese.
Yes, I would. It is very helpful in learning more Chinese language and culture, and the lesson plan is really engaging.
I would highly recommend this class to anyone at the intermediate level of Chinese study. All the teachers are great, and the subjects studied are interesting and engaging.
Yes! You learn a lot.l
